The next item of business are three proposed loans to Japan. I would like to oall on the following _Ilbers of the statt -- first Mr. Dorr and then Mr. Rabert. Mr. Dorr will give the general presentation and Mr. Rembert will discus the teCbn1cal aspects of the loan. We will not have aByone present an economic report 8. we have already had a special meeting on that.
MR. DORR: Gentlellen, there are three proposed loans here to finance the foreign exchange part ot the costs ot construction by the Kansa1, Kyushu and Chubu Power COllpan1e.  ot three tbermal pover stations. Theae power stations will lhave capacities ot 150,000, 75,000 and 66,000 kw. They viII I
â€¢ be located in the Kobe-Osaka area, the Nagoya area and in nortbern Kyusnu. As Mr. Black bas pointed out, the general d1souss1on ot the economic situation ot Japan has recently taken place in this Board, and certainly I haven' t anything to add to tbe very able remarks or Mr. Garner and my colleague Mr. de Wilde. I would just reoall that, as a background tor these loans~
I Japan is raced with the problem ot major readjustment and re- ! habilitation or her 1ndustr1al plant and her economy; that i sbe is nov in a position ot having a tev years' breath1ng space, perhaps, during the period When sbe has these extraÂ­ ordinary dollar expenditures to bolster up her position, and during that time she must try to modernize her industry and put herself in a poa1 t10D where she will be able to eam her own way in the tuture. Like certain other prom1nent countries, export or die
is her situation, and she must put herself in a position to
expand her produot1on and to make it more ett1c1ent.
Twenty percent ot her tood !lUst be imported. She spends about 25 percent ot her tore1gn exchange earnings to buy those ~ports. And ot course she must a180 ~port raw materials in order to make the things to send out to buy the tood.  5
One ot the things wh1ch 1s essent1al to th1s expans10n and improvement ot her product1ve capac1ty generally 1s the prov1s10n ot more electr1c power. She 1s already short ot i power, not only dur1ng the dry seasons, but over-all. However~ i
the shortage 1s part1cularly apparent and part1cularly burden-j I
some during the low-water per10ds v.nen the ava1lab1l1ty ot hydroelectr1c pover drops ott very sharply. It 1s est1Dlated that w1thin t1ve years an 1ncrease in demand ot at least 31 percent tor power w1ll occur. The three pover compan1es 1nvolved here operate 1n three ot the most important 1ndustr1al areas 1n Japan -- those around Kobe-Osaka, Nagoya and Kyushu. In that total area, Wh1ch 1s southwestern Japan, 67 percent ot Japanls steel 1s produced, about 57 percent ot her coal, 75 peroent ot her ceram1cs, about 58 percent ot cotton text1les, 88 percent ot wool text1les -- sh1pbu1lding, cheaical and heavy engineerÂ­ ing industries are also very ~portant.
I wonlt attempt to discuss in detail the role ot these three pover plants because Dr. Rembert 1s qualif1ed to handle that. I will just say that the expans10n otelectr1c power, thermal generat1ng power, as a result ot the construct10n ot these plants would be about ten percent. That would, ot course, add to the t1~ pover ava1lable throughout the year and make 1t poss1ble tor 1ndustry in general to operate at a
h1gber level and prevent a lot ot cap1tal equ1pment trom ly1ng  6
idle during the lov-vater period ot the Jear. In addition, theae plants vill, during periods ot less than. maximum thermal power generation, enable ye17 large I savings to be made through the substitution tor a much less II etticient plant Which nov has to be used. COIling down to the teatures ot the proposed loan, tirst the suggested terms are 20 Jears at 5 percent with am.ortizatio I beginning atter a three-Jear period. The thrâ€¢â€¢ proposed loans I are $21.5 million tor the Kansai Caapany, $11.2 million to i the Kyushu CompanJ, and $1.5 million to the Chubu Company. I The general pattern is as tollovs. There would be loan II
agreements concluded vith the Japan Developaent Bank, project agre_ents vith the three pover com.panies, and ot COUl'se a I guarautee agreement vith the Govermaent ot Japan. The GovernÂ­ ment ot Japan has asked that the loans be made by us to the Japan Developaent Bank, vhich is an agencJ ot the Japanese I Governaent .et up to ~l tore1~ fund. end government tund1 into h igh priority economic projects. As I say, the Japanese Government telt that it would be lIOst appropriate and convenient to it i t the loans vere made to the Japan Development Bank rather than the pover companies, and the Bank: management telt that that was a reasonable reques to accede to, i t ve could get the appropriate engagements fro. the power companies themselves. We haYe included in the proposed project agreements vith  7
the power compan1es many ot the prov1s1ons wh1Ch you normally f1nd 1n our loan agreementa hav1ng to do w1th the use ot the loan, the carry1ng on of the project and so forth. The three power compan1es theaaelves are pr1vately-owned compan1es. The Government 1nterest 1n two of them 1s very small 1ndeed. In the Kyushu Company 1t 1s 3 percent, 1n the Chubu Company, 2 percent. In the case of Kansa1, there 1s a ii substant1al m.1nor1ty Government 1nterest of 18 percent. !l'he Ii I, ;! ;; rest ot the stock 1nterest 1s pr1vately owned. Ii II II i! We have proposed that the Development Bank pledge to th1s II
i ' Bank as secur1ty for 1ta ob11gat1on the ob11gat1ons ot the II power compan1e a to the Development Bank. The undertak1ng ot I: Ii those ob11gat1ons by the power compan1es to the Developaent II Bank w111 carry w1th 1t-an automat1c pr1or1ty under Japanese II law 1n favor of the Development Bank over all existing
cred1tors, and by this pledge, we would get the benet1t of that pr1or1ty. One other feature ot the transact10n Wh1ch may be ot 1nterest 1s the covenant wh1Ch has been entered into w1th regard to power rates. As you all know, there haa been a very severe 1nflat1on 1n Japan s1nce betore the war. The pr1ce index 1s now about 350 ttmes -- not 350 percent -- 350 ttmes what 1t was. Power rates, however, are only 90 t1Bes as h1gh. Therefore you can see there has been a very severe I' lag 1n the earning power of the power industry. That has  8-9
meant~ naturally~ a dearth ot tunds tor the very necessary expansion and has made it necessary tor the Government to contemplate assisting the industry to a very large extent. We have discussed with the Government ot Japan~ and it itself has even betore we discussed it recognized that the pattern or power rates is not one which could be continued indetinitely into the tuture~ and it has expressed its inÂ­ tention to us ot establishing and maintaining rates on a basis which will give a reasonable return on the investment and permit some retention or earnings so tbat at least to a partial extent the absolutely necessary expansion can be tinanced by the electric power consumers themselves. This is~ I think, an entire tollowing out of what our President explained at the last Annual Meeting, in whiCh, you I recall~ he gave~ in a way which I donÂ·t think I could improve I on~ tbe conSiderations which led towards the desirability ot baving at least some ot the financing ot expansion done by the consumers themselves. These power stations' equipment will be bought trom two American suppliers -- Westinghouse and General Electric. Contracts have already been signed. Those companies have agreed to participate in this loan to the extent of 25 perÂ­ ri cent ot their purchase prioe, andA.the purchase price T/uJ: i:.88 to I Ix be received by their prinoipal suppliers, like the boiler I
companies. Asswming full escalation~ that means that I
I I I  10
West1nghouse w1ll part1c1pate 1n these loans to the extent of $4.9 m1ll10n and the Internat10nal General Electr1c to the extent of $1.24 m1llion. These compan1es would rece1ve the early matur1t1es and be pa1d out by July l~ 1960. I th1nk that 1s all that 1s necessary to add to what has already been fully set out 1n the President's report~
and ot course I would be glad to answer any quest10ns I can. I would just say 1n conclus10n that I am thoroughly ,i !
conv1nced that the carry1ng out of these projects w1ll ma.ke !I
a substant1al and s1gn1t1cant contr1but10n to the readjustment,! I and strengthening ot the Japanese econOllY wh1ch 1s necessary I it she 1s to earn her own way in the future. I
THE CBAIRMAlf: Thank you very much~ Mr. Dorr. I will calIon Dr. Rembert before we have any quest10ns. DR. REMBERT: Gentlemen, you have rece1ved a rather deta1led report on these projects, so I w1ll conf1ne my remarks to a short summary ot our f1nd1ngs. In Japan tuel 1s both scarce and expens1ve, and these factors have been the pr1nc1pal cons1derat10n in t1xing the des1gn and the select10n ot equ1pment tor these projects. . They represent a balance between Investment cost and operatlnl cost~ and we cons1der that the select10n has been in line ~ w1th good eng1neering pract1ce. We think the projects are techn1cally sound. Inc1Â­ dentally, these are the largest and most eft1c1ent un1ts  11
that the Bank has ever financed in any of its thermal poe r
projects. The estimated cost or the total installations varies from $195 to $215 per 1nstal1ed k11ovatt, vh1Ch compares favorably v1th the other projects vh1ch the Bank has f1nanced. I In fact, this cost is slightly lover than the average of the I I thermal projects vh1ch ve have f1nanced to date. We consider I this cost to be entirely reasonable. The companies vh1Ch v1ll own and operate these projects I are large enterprises, even when compared with utilit7 campanil. 1n the United States and other parts of the vorl~. They I I
1nvo1ve both hydro and stesa pover generation along with very extensive transa1ss1on and ~1str1but1on works. While the,. vere established onl,. 1n 1951, they are 1n reality not nev companies 1n relation to management and operat1ng personnel. It vas simply a reorganization of the
ut111t,. systems in Japan resulting from denationalization of national power companies that had been established during the , war. We consider that the management and operating personnel are thoroughly experienced and competent to carryon an enterprise of this type. Each of these projects is a part of more extensive expansion prosr.8ms to be carried out by the three companies. Most of the work in these programs is 81ther under  12
. construction at the present time or tully committed. Each company also has an improvement program designed to reduce S7stam 10S88S and improve the general operating etticlenC7 01' their generat10g plants. We consider the execution ot these programs as essentlal to the continued operation ot these companies as sound utilities~ and ve have theretore required assurances as to the completion 01' both the improvement and expansion programs. I'ow~ on the f10ancial side~ the present and future capital structures 01' the companies leaves sODething to be desired. Tbe proportion 01' abare capital in each ot them is very thin, but it rather large revaluation reserves are taken into account~ the debt eqult7 ratio will be, on completion ot these prOgrUls, somewhat better than two to one. As 10 the case or most utility companies throughout the world today, the tinancial soundness and their abl1ity to tlnance tuture expansion depends on an adequate rate structure. In the case ot these companies, rate increases ot trom 10 to 30 percent will be required to keep them in a sound posi tion. The Governaant has recognlzed this 8ituation and will undertake to establish rates which are required tor this purpose. THE CRAIRMAll: Thank you, sir. Any questions? Any
discussion ot the loan? It there are no questions, may I have a motion to adopt the toree resolutions.  13
MR. OVERBY: I so move. MR. HEURT~TE: Second.
THE ClIAIRMAll': All in favor s a7 II a7e." (Chorus of II aye s. " ) Opposed. (No response) MR. BOPPEI'OT: Mr. Chairman, I want to be recorded as abstaining. THE CHA:IRlCAN: I declare the loans of $21.5 million, $11.2 million and $7.5 million to the Japanese Development Bank approved b.,the Board.

doc.repnme: Transcript of two-hundred forty-sixth regular meeting of the Executive Directors of the Bank, held on Thursday, October 15, 1953
doc.abstracts: This transcript, from the session of the Executive Directors held on Thursday, October 15, 1953 covers only the discussion on two-hundred forty-sixth regular meeting of the loans to Japan.
